spell.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to form a word by writing or naming the letters in order
spell.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Pupils should know how to spell commonly used words.
spell.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if letters spell a word, they form it
spell.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to do someone else’s work for them for a short period so that they can rest
spell.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I can spell you if you get tired.
spell.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a piece of magic that someone does, or the special words or ceremonies used in doing it
spell.translation[1].definitions[0].note: put/cast a spell on somebody (=do a piece of magic to change someone)
spell.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The kiss of the prince broke the spell  (=stopped the magic from working).
The whole town seemed to be under a spell.
spell.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a period of a particular kind of activity, weather, illness etc, usually a short period
spell.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: a day of sunny spells and scattered showers
He began to suffer from dizzy spells.
After a brief spell in the army, I returned to teaching.
Water the young plants carefully during dry spells.
spell.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a power that attracts, interests, and influences you very strongly
spell.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: an ancient city that still casts its spell over travellers
I fell under the spell of her charm.
spell.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: a piece of magic that someone does, or the special words or ceremonies used in doing it
spell.translation[1].note_box[0].section: She found an ancient book of magic spells.
The people still believe in evil spells.
Suddenly everyone froze, as if a wizard had cast a spell on them.
She wove a spell, so that he slept forever and never grew old.
The fairy put a terrible spell on the princess.
No one knew how to break the spell.
spell.translation[1].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: a period of a particular kind of activity, weather, illness etc, usually a short period
spell.translation[1].note_box[1].section: After a brief spell in a florist's shop, she became a hairdresser.
We have just had a long spell of unusually dry weather.
Keep fuchsias well watered during prolonged dry spells in summer.
There was a very cold spell in late November.
Tuesday will be dry with sunny spells.
She must have had a dizzy spell and fallen.
The team had some good spells during the match.
We've had quite a quiet spell at work recently.
